title: 114_hr921
content: The Act may be cited as the "Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act of 2016" and provides protections for covered sports medicine professionals. The "Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act of 2016" provides medical professional liability insurance coverage for covered sports medicine professionals who provide services in a secondary state to athletes or athletic teams. The coverage extends to services provided in the secondary state as if they were provided in the primary state. The "Sports Medicine Licensure Clarity Act of 2016" allows licensed professionals to provide services to athletes in a secondary state if they are licensed in the primary state. The Act defines an athlete as someone participating in a paid sporting event, sponsored by a national governing body, or covered by a high school or institution of higher education. The term "athletic team" refers to a sports team with individuals who are paid to participate, involved in events sanctioned by a governing body, or supported by a school with a sports medicine professional. Covered medical services include general care, emergency care, athletic training, and physical therapy, excluding care provided at a healthcare facility. Covered sports medicine professional refers to a licensed health care provider who offers medical services to athletes under a written agreement, after disclosing the nature of the services. The term "health care facility" refers to a facility providing medical care on an inpatient or outpatient basis, excluding facilities at arenas, stadiums, or temporary event facilities. The term "institution of higher education" is defined as per the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "national governing body" is defined in U.S.C. 1001. The "primary State" for a covered sports medicine professional is where they are licensed to practice and where the majority of their practice is underwritten for liability insurance. The "secondary State" is any State that is not the primary State. The term "State" includes all States, the District of Columbia, and commonwealths. The term "State" includes all States, the District of Columbia, and each commonwealth, territory, or possession of the United States. The House of Representatives passed the document on September 12, 2016, with Karen L. Haas as the Clerk.
